description: From Middle English harlot, from Old French harlot, herlot, arlot (“vagabond; tramp”), of obscure origin. Likely ultimately of Germanic origin, either from a derivation of *harjaz (“army; camp; warrior; military leader”) or from a diminutive of *karilaz (“man; fellow”). Compare English carlot.

adjectives.description: harlot (comparative more harlot, superlative most harlot)

entries.meaning: (derogatory, offensive) A female who is considered promiscuous.
examples: Synonyms: skeezer, slut, whore; see also Thesaurus:promiscuous woman

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A churl; a common man; a person, male or female, of low birth, especially one given to low conduct.

verbs.description: harlot (third-person singular simple present harlots, present participle harloting or harlotting, simple past and past participle harloted or harlotted)

entries.meaning: To play the harlot; to practice lewdness.
